content: People have different opinions on whether this counts as a solution to Freek's problem. I personally don't really care. Even if it doesn't count, I would be happy to merge this PR. What do others think?
@Floris van Doorn Currently the PR doesn't change 100.yaml. Are you happy to merge it given that fact?

It feels a bit weird to have this solution in 100-theorems-list but not update 100.yaml, so probably we should update that.
I'm not against merging this if other people think this is worth having and/or counts as a solution to the 100 problems list.

I've added the 100.yaml entry.

Euler's solution to the Konigsberg problem was to consider sequences of letters ABCAD... such that letters are consecutive iff the corresponding bodies of land are connected by a bridge and such that unordered pairs of consecutive letters appear the correct number of times. So perhaps the more Eulerian way to model it would be a simple graph for the underlying connectivity and then look for walks whose edges are some specific multiset, rather than using multigraphs.

I can't possibly speak for Euler, but I imagine if we had the opportunity to ask him his opinion he'd wonder why the argument in this PR doesn't resolve the Konigsberg bridges problem.

I guess in some ways the reason people are hesitant is because the "theorem" behind the KÃ¶ningsberg problems holds for digraphs, so people think the bridges itself must basically include a proof of that. But I'm in favour of merging this, and further I imagine that if Mathlib gets digraphs that are not docs#quiver, the code to adapt this proof to that should take <1hr to fix.

All that said, I'll leave it to all of you to decide whether this is too controversial of an entry to add to the Freek list! :smile: I'm mostly happy that the simple graph library has developed enough that the proofs here are trivial.
@Eric Rodriguez Be careful -- you can't use just digraphs to model this because you need mutual exclusion for the pair of edges corresponding to an unoriented edge.
true! I spent an afternoon on this a while ago but I didn't think of that, actually

Note that Freek himself is extremely unfussed about what "counts" as a solution to a problem. For example IIRC one of the "proofs" of pythagoras' theorem just links to a definition of dist((a,b),(c,d)):=sqrt((a-c)^2+(b-d)^2) on R^2.
Our 100-theorems entry for Pell's equation comes with a caveat that actually it's only for a special case.
FWIW @Harun Khan is working on the general case of Pell as a summer project
